article_tonight_check_h2: How to Check If Northern Lights Are Visible Tonight
article_tonight_check_intro: Here's the step-by-step process to determine if you'll see aurora tonight:
article_tonight_check_method1_step2: Add your location (or check forecasts for {fairbanksLink}, {tromsoLink}, {reykjavikLink}, plus 50+ UK locations)
article_tonight_check_method1_step3_sub2: Kp index vs. your location's threshold
article_tonight_check_method1_step3_sub4: Best viewing hour (darkness + Kp peak overlap)
article_tonight_check_method1_step4: Enable notifications to get alerts when conditions improve (see our {alertsGuideLink} for best practices)
article_tonight_check_method2_intro: If you prefer checking manually, combine these sources:
article_tonight_check_method2_step2: Cloud forecast: Check local weather for cloud coverage
article_tonight_check_method2_step3: Moon phase: Full moon washes out faint aurora displays
article_tonight_check_method2_step4: Darkness hours: Aurora only visible after complete darkness (nautical twilight)
article_tonight_check_method2_step5: Calculate if Kp meets your threshold — See table above or use our {trackerGuideLink}
article_tonight_check_warning_intro: Many websites show "aurora forecast maps" with green ovals. These are OVATION model predictions for 60-100 km altitude. They don't account for:
article_tonight_check_warning_outro: A green OVATION oval doesn't guarantee visibility. Always cross-check with weather and darkness.
article_tonight_check_warning_title: ❌ Don't Rely on Generic "Aurora Tonight" Forecasts
article_tonight_cta_text: Don't miss the next aurora display. AuroraMe combines Kp index, cloud forecasts, moon phase, and darkness calculations to show your exact viewing chances. Free 3-day forecast + instant alerts.
article_tonight_faq1_a: Short-term forecasts (tonight, tomorrow) are 70-80% accurate when combining Kp index + weather + darkness. The NOAA OVATION model updates every 5 minutes based on real-time solar wind data. Cloud forecasts are accurate within 12 hours. The main uncertainty is intensity — aurora can be stronger or weaker than predicted.
article_tonight_faq1_q: How accurate are northern lights forecasts?
article_tonight_faq2_a: Yes, you can see it with naked eyes — if conditions are right. Faint displays (Kp 2-3) appear as pale green "clouds" or pillars. Strong displays (Kp 5+) show vivid green, pink, purple colors dancing across the sky. Cameras pick up more color due to long exposures, but naked-eye aurora during storms is spectacular.
article_tonight_faq2_q: Can I see aurora with my eyes or only with a camera?
article_tonight_faq3_a: Go outside anyway if you can. Forecasts are probability estimates, not certainties. Many aurora chasers have witnessed unexpected displays during "low probability" nights. Set your threshold to "alert me for any chance above 20%" in AuroraMe app.
article_tonight_faq3_q: What if forecast says "maybe" or "low chance"?
article_tonight_faq4_a: Winter has more viewing hours due to long darkness (6 PM – 6 AM vs. summer's limited darkness). However, geomagnetic activity has no seasonal pattern — Kp storms happen year-round. The issue is darkness, not aurora frequency. In summer above 60°N, you have "white nights" with no aurora visibility.
article_tonight_faq4_q: Is winter better than summer for aurora?
article_tonight_faq5_a: From 15 minutes to several hours. Brief "substorms" last 30-60 minutes. Major geomagnetic storms (Kp 6+) can produce aurora for 4-6 hours with breaks. The "dancing" phase (rapid movement) typically lasts 5-20 minutes within longer displays.
article_tonight_faq5_q: How long do northern lights displays last?
article_tonight_kp_h3: How Kp Requirements Change by Latitude
article_tonight_kp_infobox_text: A Kp 3 storm in Shetland can mean aurora overhead. The same Kp 3 in London means nothing visible. This is why generic Kp forecasts don't work — you need location-specific thresholds.
article_tonight_kp_intro: Aurora Activity (Kp) measures geomagnetic activity on a scale of 0-9. Think of it as the "aurora strength". For a full breakdown, see our {kpGuideLink}.
article_tonight_kp_range1: Kp 0-2: Quiet conditions — aurora usually only visible in the far north of the UK ({fairbanksLink}, {reykjavikLink}, {tromsoLink})
article_tonight_kp_range2: Kp 3-5: Moderate activity — aurora visible across northern UK ({anchorageLink}, {yellowknifeLink}, {aberdeenLink})
article_tonight_kp_range3: Kp 6-9: Strong geomagnetic storm — aurora visible as far south as {londonLink} or {newYorkLink}
article_tonight_kp_scale_caption: Example: Location requires Kp 5+ to see aurora. Current Kp 3 = not visible (red zone).
article_tonight_kp_table_intro: Here's what Kp index you need based on your magnetic latitude (MLAT):
article_tonight_kp_takeaway: Key takeaway: Don't just check "Kp index" — check if current Kp meets your location's threshold. AuroraMe does this calculation automatically for 50+ UK locations.
article_tonight_meta_description: Find out if you'll see northern lights tonight. Learn how to check real-time aurora forecasts, understand Kp index, weather conditions, and best viewing times. Beginner-friendly guide updated daily.
article_tonight_meta_hero_alt: Person checking smartphone with vibrant green northern lights dancing over snowy forest at night
article_tonight_meta_title: Will I See Northern Lights Tonight? Complete Guide
article_tonight_mistake1_right: Reality: Clouds can be 100%, moon can be full, or it's still twilight. Always check all three factors.
article_tonight_mistake1_wrong: Mistake: "Kp is 5 tonight, I'll definitely see aurora!"
article_tonight_mistake2_right: Reality: Kp 9 storms happen 2-3 times per solar cycle (11 years). If you live above 60°N, Kp 2-3 displays are spectacular and frequent.
article_tonight_mistake2_wrong: Mistake: "I'll only go out when there's a huge storm."
article_tonight_mistake3_right: Reality: Wait for full darkness (nautical twilight ends). Aurora is there, but invisible in twilight.
article_tonight_mistake3_wrong: Mistake: Checking at 8 PM when there's still a blue glow in the sky.
article_tonight_mistake4_right: Reality: Light pollution washes out faint aurora. Drive 15-30 minutes outside city limits for dark skies.
article_tonight_mistake4_wrong: Mistake: Watching from a well-lit street or downtown area.
article_tonight_mistake5_right: Reality: Aurora activity fluctuates. Stay outside for 30-60 minutes during favorable conditions. Many displays start faint and intensify over time.
article_tonight_mistake5_wrong: Mistake: "I looked for 10 minutes, saw nothing, went back inside."
article_tonight_mistakes_h2: 5 Mistakes Beginners Make (And How to Avoid Them)

article_tonight_time_h2: What Time Should I Go Outside?
article_tonight_time_important: Important: Aurora can appear anytime during darkness hours. The "10 PM – 2 AM" window is just statistically most active. If Kp is high and skies are clear at 9 PM, go outside immediately — don't wait for "the perfect time."
article_tonight_time_intro: Aurora is visible only in complete darkness. This means:
article_tonight_time_rule1: Not during twilight — Even dim "blue hour" light washes out aurora
article_tonight_time_rule2: Not during summer — Locations above 60°N have 24-hour daylight in June/July
article_tonight_time_rule3: Best hours: 10 PM – 2 AM local time — Statistical peak for aurora activity
article_tonight_time_table_intro: The best time varies by season and latitude. In general:
article_tonight_weather_cloud1: 0-20% clouds: Perfect conditions — clear view of aurora
article_tonight_weather_cloud2: 20-50% clouds: Partially visible — you might see aurora through gaps
article_tonight_weather_cloud3: 50-80% clouds: Mostly obscured — brief glimpses only
article_tonight_weather_cloud4: 80-100% clouds: Completely blocked — go back inside
article_tonight_weather_h2: Why Weather Matters (Even with High Kp)
article_tonight_weather_img_alt: Split-screen comparison: left shows clear starry night with aurora, right shows cloudy overcast sky
article_tonight_weather_intro: You can have a Kp 9 geomagnetic superstorm, but if there are clouds above you, you'll see nothing. Aurora happens 60-300 miles above Earth — clouds at 1-2 miles altitude completely block the view.
article_tonight_weather_moon_text: Full moon creates "light pollution" that washes out faint aurora. Best viewing: new moon (0% illumination) or during moon-free hours (after moonset, before moonrise). Strong aurora (Kp 6+) are still visible with full moon, but faint displays disappear.
article_tonight_weather_protip: Pro tip: Use live weather radar to find gaps in clouds. Sometimes driving 20-30 minutes to a clear patch makes the difference between seeing aurora or not.
article_tonight_where_cta: Check live forecasts for your specific city on {homepageLink} — we track aurora visibility for 50+ UK locations.

bt_autumn_desc: The autumn equinox brings the year's strongest aurora activity. September and October offer the perfect combination of high geomagnetic activity, increasing darkness, and relatively mild weather.
bt_booking_li2: Plan minimum 3-5 nights for weather flexibility
bt_booking_li3: Avoid full moon periods for darker skies
bt_booking_li4: Check local weather patterns and cloud statistics
bt_cta_alerts: Get instant alerts when northern lights are visible in {location}.
bt_cta_track: Track real-time activity and receive notifications 30 minutes before aurora appears.
bt_faq_a1_best_month: {month} is statistically the best month with {score}% activity rate and {hours} hours of darkness. The autumn equinox effect creates a significant spike in geomagnetic activity, giving you the highest chances of witnessing the northern lights.
bt_faq_a2_summer_normal: Summer viewing is extremely challenging due to white nights and limited darkness (only {hours} hours in June). Only the strongest geomagnetic storms (Kp 7+) might be visible low on the northern horizon.
bt_faq_a2_summer_polar: No, the midnight sun from mid-May to late July makes aurora viewing impossible. The sun doesn't set during this period, eliminating the darkness needed to see aurora.
bt_faq_a3_nights: Plan for at least 3-5 nights in {location} to account for weather and aurora activity variations. With a 5-night stay during {month1} or {month2}, you have approximately 80-90% chance of seeing aurora if Kp reaches {kp} or higher.

bt_h1_title: Best time to see the northern lights in {location}
bt_intro_based_on: Based on {mlat}° magnetic latitude and historical aurora patterns, the optimal viewing season in {location} runs from {start} through {end}.
bt_intro_peak_activity: Peak aurora activity occurs during the {month} equinox with up to {hours} hours of darkness.
bt_photo_li2: New moon periods offer darkest skies
bt_quality_good_desc: Regular displays in autumn and winter
bt_spring_desc: The spring equinox in March brings another activity peak. April still offers good viewing before the summer twilight begins. May marks the transition to challenging summer conditions.
bt_success_li4: Be ready to move for clear skies
bt_summer_desc_normal: Limited darkness and white nights make summer aurora viewing extremely challenging. Only the strongest storms may be visible.
bt_summer_desc_polar: The midnight sun makes aurora viewing impossible from mid-May to late July. Focus on planning autumn trips.
bt_weather_li1: Clear skies essential - clouds block aurora
bt_weather_li2_coastal: Coastal areas may have more clouds
bt_weather_li3: Inland locations often have clearer skies
bt_winter_desc: Winter provides the longest nights and clearest skies, ideal for aurora photography. While activity is slightly lower than equinox months, the extended darkness offers more viewing opportunities.
city_faq_a1_full: Yes! While bright moonlight can wash out faint auroras, it also illuminates the landscape beautifully. During strong aurora activity (high status), the lights are bright enough to see even with a full moon. The app helps you balance moon phases with aurora intensity for optimal viewing.
city_faq_a2_prefix: Not necessarily. Based on {name}'s magnetic latitude
city_faq_a2_suffix: you typically need Kp {kpThreshold}+ for good visibility. The app calculates precise local thresholds and sends alerts only when aurora is likely visible from your specific location.
city_faq_a3_suffix: when nights are longest and skies darkest. Activity peaks around equinoxes (March/September) due to solar wind interactions. Download the app for seasonal patterns and 27-day aurora history.
city_faq_a4_full: Both work! The aurora is visible across a wide area. Dark sky locations away from city lights offer better visibility, but aurora can be seen from {name} during strong activity. The app includes recent sightings feed to see where others spotted aurora nearby.
city_faq_a5_full: Aurora activity can happen anytime when dark, but peak hours are typically 22:00-02:00 local time. For precise timing, download the app for 72-hour forecasting with best hour recommendations based on Kp peaks, cloud breaks, and optimal darkness windows.
city_faq_a6_full: Our system combines multiple data sources (NOAA, GFZ) with local factors like magnetic latitude, weather, and twilight calculations. The app provides location-specific thresholds and smart low-noise alerts to avoid false positives. Accuracy improves closer to the event time.

cookie_manage_item1: Use your browser settings to block or delete cookies.

faq_q1_answer: The activity level needed depends on your location's aurora zone. Locations closer to the poles need less activity. Check your local activity threshold on the city page — we calculate it based on your position.
faq_q1_hint: The activity level needed depends on your location's aurora zone. Locations closer to the poles need less activity. Check your local activity threshold on the city page.
faq_q1_question: What activity level do I need?
faq_q2_answer: Use the 'best hour tonight' on each city page; it's based on KP, clouds and darkness window.
faq_q3_answer: You need darkness — twilight or bright moonlight reduces visibility considerably.
faq_q3_question: Can I see aurora in summer?
faq_q4_answer: AuroraMe combines 4 reality factors: NOAA OVATION space weather, cloud coverage, moon phase, and darkness windows. Location-specific KP thresholds are calibrated from 3+ years of historical data (8,768+ measurements). This multi-factor approach is significantly more accurate than single-source KP predictions.
faq_q5_answer: Aurora History provides multi-year statistical analysis: best months algorithm showing top viewing months, calendar heatmap (12 months × 4 weeks), yesterday's observation windows, and location-calibrated frequency (e.g., Lerwick ~50 nights/year vs London ~5 nights/year).
faq_q6_answer: Quiet hours prevent notifications during sleep (default 11 PM - 7 AM, customizable per location). Progressive urgency: strong aurora activity overrides quiet hours. Each location has independent settings with 30-minute cooldown between alerts.
features_card1_text: Space weather (NOAA OVATION + KP index), cloud coverage, moon brightness, and local darkness — all analyzed together. No more "aurora possible" alerts during cloudy skies or full moon.
features_card2_text: Lerwick needs KP ≥ 2.5, London needs KP ≥ 6.0. Thresholds derived from 3+ years of historical data (8,768+ measurements). Results match actual aurora frequency: ~30 nights/year in Shetland, ~2 nights/year in southern England.
features_card3_text: Push alerts arrive only during actual viewing hours: clear skies, dark conditions, sufficient activity. Quiet hours protection (customizable 11 PM - 7 AM). 30-minute cooldown prevents spam.
features_card4_text: Now: Real-time status updating every 5-10 minutes. Tonight: 12-72 hour detailed forecast. This month: 27-day trend calendar. History: 3+ years statistical analysis with best months algorithm.

privacy_meta_description: How AuroraMe handles personal data for auroraforecast.uk and Lemon Squeezy purchases.
privacy_mor_body: Payments are processed by Lemon Squeezy, Inc. acting as Merchant of Record. Paddle.net may be introduced later; the checkout page will always show the active provider.
privacy_rights_body: Depending on where you live you may have the right to:
privacy_rights_item1: Access or receive a copy of your personal data.
privacy_rights_item3: Request deletion when data is no longer needed or legally required.
privacy_rights_item4: Object to or restrict processing based on legitimate interests.
privacy_rights_item5: Withdraw cookie consent at any time.
privacy_rights_item6: File a complaint with your supervisory authority.
privacy_security_body: We use HTTPS, role-based access, logging, and short retention periods for tokens and logs. No payment card data is stored on AuroraMe servers.
privacy_sharing_body: We share data only with trusted providers under data processing agreements:
privacy_sharing_item1: Lemon Squeezy, Inc. (USA) – Merchant of Record, billing, fraud prevention, tax compliance.
privacy_sharing_item2: Google LLC – Google Analytics 4 with EU data region and IP anonymization.
privacy_sharing_item3: Firebase / Google Cloud – hosting, authentication, and Firestore storage in the EU region.
privacy_sharing_item4: Google Workspace (Gmail) – support mailbox and customer communication.
privacy_sharing_item5: Paddle.net – standby Merchant of Record (inactive at launch).
privacy_transfers_body: Data may be stored or processed in the EU and United States. Transfers rely on Standard Contractual Clauses plus encryption and access controls.
privacy_usage_description: We rely on the following grounds under GDPR/UK GDPR and similar laws:
privacy_usage_item1_body: Process purchases, send receipts, grant Premium Access, and support your account.
privacy_usage_item2_body: Maintain accounting records, collect taxes, and respond to lawful requests.
privacy_usage_item3_body: Prevent fraud, monitor abuse, and improve site reliability.
privacy_usage_item4_body: EU/UK visitors provide consent before GA4 cookies load.
regions_nav_intro: Explore multi-state aurora viewing regions with comprehensive coverage across prime northern lights zones.
state_cities_showing: Showing top {count} {explanation}. {name} has {total} total aurora viewing locations.
state_cta_subtitle: Get real-time notifications when northern lights are visible in your area.
state_darksky_check_cities: Check our city pages for specific dark sky recommendations near each location.
state_darksky_map_desc: Interactive map showing {type} in {name}. Click markers for details and directions.
state_darksky_photo_desc: These sites offer minimal light pollution for optimal aurora photography.
state_darksky_type_preserves: dark sky preserves and Bortle class sites
state_faq_a1_yes: Yes, {name} {region} offers aurora viewing opportunities. Cities like {city} (MLAT {mlat}°) can see aurora at Kp {kp_min}+, while southern locations need Kp {kp_max}+. Best viewing is September–April during dark, clear nights.
state_faq_a2_sites: The darkest locations include {sites} with Bortle class {min}–{max}.
state_faq_q1: Can you see the northern lights in {name}?
state_faq_q2: Where are the darkest skies in {name}?
state_footer_best_time: Best time to see aurora in {name}
state_header_intro_region: Comprehensive aurora monitoring across {name} region with live visibility tracking, weather integration, and optimal viewing time predictions.
state_header_intro_state: Complete aurora forecast system for {name} featuring real-time magnetic activity monitoring, cloud cover analysis, and precision timing for {count} cities.
state_header_subtitle: Real-time aurora predictions, alerts, and viewing conditions across {count} monitored locations
state_meta_description: Live aurora forecast for {count} cities in {name}. Real-time northern lights visibility with required Kp {kp}.
terms_changes_body: We may update these Terms to reflect new features, processors, or legal requirements. Material updates will be posted with a new “Last updated” date, and continued use constitutes acceptance.
terms_contact_address: AuroraMe, Carrer de Pau Claris 138, 08009 Barcelona, Spain
terms_contact_body: Email {emailLink} or write to {address}. Include your Lemon Squeezy order ID for billing inquiries.
terms_disclaimer_body1: Aurora forecasts depend on weather and space-weather inputs outside our control. Premium Access is provided “as is” without warranties of accuracy, reliability, or fitness for a particular purpose.
terms_disclaimer_body2: You remain solely responsible for travel or outdoor decisions based on the data.
terms_eligibility_body: You must have legal capacity to contract and comply with these Terms.
terms_eligibility_item1: Minimum age 13 (or higher if required by local law).
terms_eligibility_item2: If you act on behalf of an organization, you confirm you have authority to bind it.
terms_eligibility_item3: You are responsible for safeguarding access tokens, emails, and any activity performed through them.
terms_indemnity_body: You agree to indemnify AuroraMe, its affiliates, and processors against claims resulting from your misuse of the site, violation of these Terms, or infringement of third-party rights.
terms_intro_body1: These Terms of Use & Sale ("Terms") govern your access to auroraforecast.uk and any premium aurora forecast products ("Premium Access"). By visiting the site or purchasing Premium Access you agree to these Terms.
terms_intro_body2: If you disagree with these Terms, do not use the website or place an order.
terms_law_body1: If you are a consumer in the EU or UK, mandatory consumer laws of your country apply and disputes may be brought to your local courts.
terms_law_body2: All other users agree that Spanish law governs these Terms and that disputes will be resolved in the courts of Barcelona, Spain, except where mandatory local law requires otherwise.
terms_liability_body: To the fullest extent permitted by law, AuroraMe and its processors will not be liable for indirect, incidental, special, consequential, or punitive damages, or any amount exceeding what you paid during the preceding 6 months.
terms_license_usage_body: AuroraMe grants you a limited, non-transferable license to view purchased premium data for personal, non-commercial use during the stated access window.
terms_license_usage_item1: Do not resell, publish, or redistribute premium data.
terms_license_usage_item2: No scraping, bulk exporting, or reverse engineering of the website or APIs.
terms_license_usage_item3: We may suspend access for abuse, fraud, or any violation of these Terms.
terms_meta_description: Legal terms covering AuroraMe web usage and premium digital purchases handled by Lemon Squeezy.
terms_mor_body: AuroraMe sells digital products through Lemon Squeezy, Inc. (12121 Bluff Creek Dr Ste 300, Playa Vista, CA 90094, USA), which processes payments and issues tax receipts. Paddle.net may be added later; the checkout screen will always show the active merchant. Questions? Email support@aurorame.com or mail AuroraMe, Carrer de Pau Claris 138, 08009 Barcelona, Spain.
terms_orders_body: All prices appear on the checkout screen in your selected currency and include any applicable sales tax, VAT, or GST handled by the Merchant of Record.
terms_orders_item1: Orders are confirmed only after the Merchant of Record successfully charges your payment method and sends a receipt.
terms_orders_item2: Premium Access is provisioned immediately. You acknowledge that your statutory cooling-off right for digital content ends once delivery starts.
terms_orders_item3: We may update product descriptions or prices at any time for future orders; changes do not affect completed purchases.
terms_orders_item4: Chargebacks filed without first contacting support may result in immediate suspension while the dispute is investigated.
terms_privacy_body: Personal data is handled according to our {privacyLink}.
terms_refunds_body: Because delivery is instant, all sales are final unless Premium Access is unavailable due to our fault for more than 24 consecutive hours.
terms_refunds_item1: Submit refund requests to support@aurorame.com within 30 days and include your Lemon Squeezy order ID.
terms_refunds_item2: We may offer goodwill remedies when required by mandatory consumer laws.
terms_refunds_item3: If your region grants a cooling-off period for digital content, you consent to immediate delivery and waive that period once access begins.
terms_refunds_item4: Repeated chargebacks or fraud will lead to permanent account bans.
terms_services_body: AuroraMe provides free educational content plus paid Premium Access tiers that unlock extended forecasts for a limited time window.
terms_services_item1: Free content: guides, trackers, and location insights provided for informational purposes.
terms_services_item2: Premium Access: time-limited unlocks (72 hours, 30 days, or 12-month trend packs) for extended KP forecasts, hourly data, and historical trends.
terms_services_item3: No hardware, shipping, or notifications are included with web purchases. Mobile app alerts require a separate in-app subscription.
testimonial1_text: Finally an app that actually works! Got alerts 2 hours before the aurora appeared over Shetland. Perfect timing to get outside and see an amazing show.
testimonial2_text: The historical data helped me plan a Highlands trip perfectly. Knew exactly when and where to go. Caught auroras on two clear nights.
testimonial3_text: Smart notifications with quiet hours are a game changer. No more 3 AM alerts when I'm sleeping. Only get notified when it is visible from Northumberland.
tracker_check_back: No locations with visible aurora right now. Check back soon or enable notifications in the app.
tracker_gallery_subtitle_empty: No locations with visible aurora right now. Check back soon or enable notifications in the app.
tracker_gallery_subtitle_visible: Aurora is currently visible in {count} locations. Real-time data updated every 20 minutes.
tracker_gallery_title: 🌟 Where Aurora is Visible Right Now
tracker_hero_subtitle: Real-time UK aurora visibility with cloud cover, moon phase, and darkness.
tracker_kp_disclaimer: Important: We factor in more than just KP — cloud cover, moon phase, and darkness all affect visibility. Even with high KP, you won't see aurora if clouds block the sky or during full moon.
tracker_kp_range_0_2: KP 0-2: Weak activity — visible only in far north (Shetland, Orkney)
tracker_kp_range_3_5: KP 3-5: Moderate — visible in northern UK (Inverness, Aberdeen, Belfast)
tracker_kp_range_6_7: KP 6-7: Strong — visible across much of the UK (Manchester, Birmingham, London)
tracker_kp_range_8_9: KP 8-9: Extreme — visible across the UK, even southern England (rare events)
tracker_kp_range_extreme_text: Extreme — visible across the UK, even southern England (rare events)
tracker_kp_range_low_text: Weak activity — visible only in far north (Shetland, Orkney)
tracker_kp_range_moderate_text: Moderate — visible in northern UK (Inverness, Aberdeen, Belfast)
tracker_kp_range_strong_text: Strong — visible across much of the UK (Manchester, Birmingham, London)
tracker_kp_what_description: The KP index measures geomagnetic activity on a scale from 0 to 9. Higher KP means stronger aurora that can be seen further south from the magnetic poles.
tracker_kp_what_text: The KP index measures geomagnetic activity on a scale from 0 to 9. Higher KP means stronger aurora that can be seen further south from the magnetic poles.
tracker_meta_description: Track aurora borealis visibility across {totalCities} UK locations. Current KP {estimatedKP} — {kpLabel}. Includes cloud cover, moon phase, and darkness for accurate forecasts.
tracker_meta_title: Northern Lights Tracker — Real-Time Aurora Forecast
tracker_search_explanation: Enter a city name to see the current aurora forecast with all visibility factors
tracker_search_title: 🔍 Check Aurora Visibility in Your City
tracker_visible_now_title: Where Aurora is Visible Right Now
tracker_visible_subtitle: Aurora is currently visible in {count} locations. Real-time data updated every 20 minutes.
city_aurora_visibility_desc: Real-time aurora visibility status based on magnetic activity, weather conditions, moon phase and sky darkness.
city_featured_location: {name} is our featured location in {country}. Discover aurora viewing opportunities across the UK:
city_no_other_cities: No other cities available in {country} at the moment.
city_forecast_unavailable: 6-hour forecast temporarily unavailable. Check back in a few minutes.
city_forecast_unavailable_message: Detailed hourly forecast is temporarily unavailable.
city_forecast_check_back: Current aurora status is shown above. Check back in a few minutes for the timeline.
download_app_description: Get real-time aurora alerts and detailed forecasts on your phone.
app_screens_title_template: Experience the complete aurora forecast in {name}
app_screens_subtitle: Real screenshots from the AuroraMe app showing detailed forecasts for your location.
cross_link_best_time_full: Best time to see aurora in {name}
app_screenshot_alt: AuroraMe app screenshot showing aurora forecast timeline
feature_short_term_outlook: Short-term outlook for the next few days
status_desc_very_low: Aurora is unlikely to be visible.
status_desc_low: Aurora might be visible on the horizon.
status_desc_high: Aurora visible overhead and very bright.
near_me_faq_1_text: Aurora visibility depends on your magnetic latitude, not just geographic latitude. Our app calculates this automatically for your exact position.
near_me_faq_2_text: To see the aurora, you need dark skies. Even if activity is high, city lights can wash out the view. Drive 15-30 minutes away from city centers.
near_me_faq_3_text: Clouds are the biggest enemy of aurora hunters. Check our real-time cloud cover maps before heading out.
near_me_faq_title: Can I see the Northern Lights from my location?
near_me_status_error: Unable to retrieve your location. Please search manually.
near_me_status_not_found: Could not find a nearby city in our database.
near_me_status_unsupported: Geolocation is not supported by your browser
near_me_subtitle: Locate the best aurora viewing spots in your area instantly
tracker_map_credit: Source: NOAA Space Weather Prediction Center. Updated every 30 minutes.
monthly_trends_description: This calendar shows likelihood trends based on aurora activity, darkness, aurora zone, moonlight, and historical data. Clouds are excluded due to low predictability. Use it to pick promising nights, then confirm with the 72h forecast closer to date.
yearly_seasonal_description: This calendar shows how often aurora was observed here by week across the year. Colors reflect historical intensity: greener months had more aurora nights, grey had little or none. Use it to plan trips around the strongest months, then confirm exact nights with the 72h forecast.
yearly_upgrade_prompt: Upgrade to find optimal travel dates.
cta_72h_subtitle_a: Hour-by-hour forecast with clouds, moon & Kp
cta_72h_title_b: See Exactly When to Look Up
cta_72h_subtitle_b: 3-day precision forecast — know the best hour
cta_27d_subtitle_a: Full month view — pick dates before booking
cta_yearly_subtitle_a: 11 years of data + live 3D aurora globe
cta_yearly_subtitle_b: Historical patterns reveal the best months
